audit.description: Ensure nodev option set on /home partition.
audit.impact: An attacker could mount a special device (e.g. block or character device) on the /home partition.
audit.remediation: Edit the /etc/fstab file and nodev the fourth field (mounting options) for the /home partition. See the fstab(5) manual page for more information.

audit.description: Ensure nodev option set on /tmp partition.
audit.impact: An attacker could mount a special device (e.g. block or character device) on the /tmp partition.
audit.remediation: Edit the /etc/fstab file and nodev the fourth field (mounting options) for the /tmp partition. See the fstab(5) manual page for more information.

audit.description: Ensure nodev option set on /var/tmp partition.
audit.impact: An attacker could mount a special device (e.g. block or character device) on the /var/tmp partition.
audit.remediation: Edit the /etc/fstab file and nodev the fourth field (mounting options) for the /var/tmp partition. See the fstab(5) manual page for more information.

audit.description: Ensure nosuid option set on /tmp partition.
audit.impact: Since the /tmp filesystem is only intended for temporary file storage, set this option to ensure that users cannot create setuid files in /var/tmp.
audit.remediation: Edit the /etc/fstab file and nosuid the fourth field (mounting options) for the /tmp partition. See the fstab(5) manual page for more information.

audit.description: Ensure nosuid option set on /var/tmp partition.
audit.impact: Since the /var/tmp filesystem is only intended for temporary file storage, set this option to ensure that users cannot create setuid files in /var/tmp.
audit.remediation: Edit the /etc/fstab file and nosuid the fourth field (mounting options) for the /var/tmp partition. See the fstab(5) manual page for more information.

audit.description: Ensure noexec option set on /var/tmp partition.
audit.impact: Since the `/var/tmp` filesystem is only intended for temporary file storage, set this option to ensure that users cannot run executable binaries from `/var/tmp` .
audit.remediation: Edit the /etc/fstab file and add noexec to the fourth field (mounting options) for the /var/tmp partition. See the fstab(5) manual page for more information.

audit.description: Ensure noexec option set on /dev/shm partition.
audit.impact: Setting this option on a file system prevents users from executing programs from shared memory. This deters users from introducing potentially malicious software on the system.
audit.remediation: Edit the /etc/fstab file and add noexec to the fourth field (mounting options) for the /dev/shm partition. See the fstab(5) manual page for more information.

audit.description: Disable automounting
audit.impact: With automounting enabled anyone with physical access could attach a USB drive or disc and have its contents available in system even if they lacked permissions to mount it themselves.
audit.remediation: Disable the autofs service or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-autofs'

audit.description: Ensure mounting of USB storage devices is disabled
audit.impact: Removing support for USB storage devices reduces the local attack surface of the server.
audit.remediation: Edit or create a file in the `/etc/modprobe.d/` directory ending in .conf and add `install usb-storage /bin/true` then unload the usb-storage module or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-unnecessary-kernel-mods'

audit.description: Ensure core dumps are restricted.
audit.impact: Setting a hard limit on core dumps prevents users from overriding the soft variable. If core dumps are required, consider setting limits for user groups (see `limits.conf(5)` ). In addition, setting the `fs.suid_dumpable` variable to 0 will prevent setuid programs from dumping core.
audit.remediation: Add `hard core 0` to /etc/security/limits.conf or a file in the limits.d directory and set `fs.suid_dumpable = 0` in sysctl or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-core-dumps'

audit.description: Ensure prelink is disabled.
audit.impact: The prelinking feature can interfere with the operation of AIDE, because it changes binaries. Prelinking can also increase the vulnerability of the system if a malicious user is able to compromise a common library such as libc.
audit.remediation: uninstall `prelink` using your package manager or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r remove-prelink'

audit.description: Ensure permissions on /etc/motd are configured.
audit.impact: If the `/etc/motd` file does not have the correct ownership it could be modified by unauthorized users with incorrect or misleading information.
audit.remediation: Set the owner and group of /etc/motd to root and set permissions to 0644 or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r file-permissions'

audit.description: Ensure permissions on /etc/issue are configured.
audit.impact: If the `/etc/issue` file does not have the correct ownership it could be modified by unauthorized users with incorrect or misleading information.
audit.remediation: Set the owner and group of /etc/issue to root and set permissions to 0644 or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r file-permissions'

audit.description: Ensure permissions on /etc/issue.net are configured.
audit.impact: If the `/etc/issue.net` file does not have the correct ownership it could be modified by unauthorized users with incorrect or misleading information.
audit.remediation: Set the owner and group of /etc/issue.net to root and set permissions to 0644 or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r file-permissions'

audit.description: The nodev option should be enabled for all removable media.
audit.impact: An attacker could mount a special device (e.g. block or character device) via removable media
audit.remediation: Add the nodev option to the fourth field (mounting options) in /etc/fstab

audit.description: The noexec option should be enabled for all removable media.
audit.impact: An attacker could load executable file via removable media
audit.remediation: Add the noexec option to the fourth field (mounting options) in /etc/fstab

audit.description: The nosuid option should be enabled for all removable media.
audit.impact: An attacker could load files that run with an elevated security context via removable media
audit.remediation: Add the nosuid option to the fourth field (mounting options) in /etc/fstab

audit.description: Ensure talk client is not installed.
audit.impact: The software presents a security risk as it uses unencrypted protocols for communication.
audit.remediation: Uninstall `talk` or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r remove-talk'

audit.description: Ensure permissions on /etc/hosts.allow are configured.
audit.impact: It is critical to ensure that the `/etc/hosts.allow` file is protected from unauthorized write access. Although it is protected by default, the file permissions could be changed either inadvertently or through malicious actions.
audit.remediation: Set the owner and group of /etc/hosts.allow to root and the permissions to 0644 or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r file-permissions'

audit.description: Ensure permissions on /etc/hosts.deny are configured.
audit.impact: It is critical to ensure that the `/etc/hosts.deny` file is protected from unauthorized write access. Although it is protected by default, the file permissions could be changed either inadvertently or through malicious actions.
audit.remediation: Set the owner and group of /etc/hosts.deny to root and the permissions to 0644 or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r file-permissions'

audit.description: Ensure default deny firewall policy
audit.impact: With a default accept policy the firewall will accept any packet that is not configured to be denied. It is easier to white list acceptable usage than to black list unacceptable usage.
audit.remediation: Set the default policy for incoming, outgoing and routed traffic to `deny` or `rejecct` as appropriate using your firewall software

audit.description: The nodev/nosuid option should be enabled for all NFS mounts.
audit.impact: An attacker could load files that run with an elevated security context or special devices via remote file system
audit.remediation: Add the nosuid and nodev options to the fourth field (mounting options) in /etc/fstab

audit.description: Ensure password creation requirements are configured.
audit.impact: Strong passwords protect systems from being hacked through brute force methods.
audit.remediation: Set the following key/value pairs in the appropriate PAM for your distro: minlen=14, minclass = 4, dcredit = -1, ucredit = -1, ocredit = -1, lcredit = -1, or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r enable-password-requirements'

audit.description: Ensure lockout for failed password attempts is configured.
audit.impact: Locking out user IDs after `n` unsuccessful consecutive login attempts mitigates brute force password attacks against your systems.
audit.remediation: for Ubuntu and Debian, add the pam_tally and pam_deny modules as appropriate. For all other distros, refer to your distrobution's documentation

audit.description: Disable the installation and use of file systems that are not required (cramfs)
audit.impact: An attacker could use a vulnerability in cramfs to elevate privileges
audit.remediation: Add a file to the /etc/modprob.d directory that disables cramfs or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-unnecessary-kernel-mods'

audit.description: Disable the installation and use of file systems that are not required (freevxfs)
audit.impact: An attacker could use a vulnerability in freevxfs to elevate privileges
audit.remediation: Add a file to the /etc/modprob.d directory that disables freevxfs or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-unnecessary-kernel-mods'

audit.description: Ensure all users' home directories exist
audit.impact: If the user's home directory does not exist or is unassigned, the user will be placed in '/' and will not be able to write any files or have local environment variables set.
audit.remediation: If any users' home directories do not exist, create them and make sure the respective user owns the directory. Users without an assigned home directory should be removed or assigned a home directory as appropriate.

audit.description: Ensure users own their home directories
audit.impact: Since the user is accountable for files stored in the user home directory, the user must be the owner of the directory.
audit.remediation: Change the ownership of any home directories that are not owned by the defined user to the correct user.

audit.description: Ensure users' dot files are not group or world writable.
audit.impact: Group or world-writable user configuration files may enable malicious users to steal or modify other users' data or to gain another user's system privileges.
audit.remediation: Making global modifications to users' files without alerting the user community can result in unexpected outages and unhappy users. Therefore, it is recommended that a monitoring policy be established to report user dot file permissions and determine the action to be taken in accordance with site policy.

audit.description: Ensure no users have .forward files
audit.impact: Use of the `.forward` file poses a security risk in that sensitive data may be inadvertently transferred outside the organization. The `.forward` file also poses a risk as it can be used to execute commands that may perform unintended actions.
audit.remediation: Making global modifications to users' files without alerting the user community can result in unexpected outages and unhappy users. Therefore, it is recommended that a monitoring policy be established to report user `.forward` files and determine the action to be taken in accordance with site policy.

audit.description: Ensure no users have .netrc files
audit.impact: The `.netrc` file presents a significant security risk since it stores passwords in unencrypted form. Even if FTP is disabled, user accounts may have brought over `.netrc` files from other systems which could pose a risk to those systems
audit.remediation: Making global modifications to users' files without alerting the user community can result in unexpected outages and unhappy users. Therefore, it is recommended that a monitoring policy be established to report user `.netrc` files and determine the action to be taken in accordance with site policy.

audit.description: Ensure no users have .rhosts files
audit.impact: This action is only meaningful if `.rhosts` support is permitted in the file `/etc/pam.conf` . Even though the `.rhosts` files are ineffective if support is disabled in `/etc/pam.conf` , they may have been brought over from other systems and could contain information useful to an attacker for those other systems.
audit.remediation: Making global modifications to users' files without alerting the user community can result in unexpected outages and unhappy users. Therefore, it is recommended that a monitoring policy be established to report user `.rhosts` files and determine the action to be taken in accordance with site policy.

audit.description: Ensure all groups in /etc/passwd exist in /etc/group
audit.impact: Groups defined in the `/etc/passwd` file but not in the `/etc/group` file pose a threat to system security since group permissions are not properly managed.
audit.remediation: For each group defined in /etc/passwd, ensure there is a corresponding group in /etc/group

audit.description: Ensure no duplicate UIDs exist
audit.impact: Users must be assigned unique UIDs for accountability and to ensure appropriate access protections.
audit.remediation: Establish unique UIDs and review all files owned by the shared UIDs to determine which UID they are supposed to belong to.

audit.description: Ensure no duplicate GIDs exist
audit.impact: Groups must be assigned unique GIDs for accountability and to ensure appropriate access protections.
audit.remediation: Establish unique GIDs and review all files owned by the shared GIDs to determine which GID they are supposed to belong to.

audit.description: Ensure no duplicate user names exist
audit.impact: If a user is assigned a duplicate user name, it will create and have access to files with the first UID for that username in `/etc/passwd` . For example, if 'test4' has a UID of 1000 and a subsequent 'test4' entry has a UID of 2000, logging in as 'test4' will use UID 1000. Effectively, the UID is shared, which is a security problem.
audit.remediation: Establish unique user names for the users. File ownerships will automatically reflect the change as long as the users have unique UIDs.

audit.description: Ensure no duplicate groups exist
audit.impact: If a group is assigned a duplicate group name, it will create and have access to files with the first GID for that group in `/etc/group` . Effectively, the GID is shared, which is a security problem.
audit.remediation: Establish unique names for the user groups. File group ownerships will automatically reflect the change as long as the groups have unique GIDs.

audit.description: Ensure shadow group is empty
audit.impact: Any users assigned to the shadow group would be granted read access to the /etc/shadow file. If attackers can gain read access to the `/etc/shadow` file, they can easily run a password cracking program against the hashed passwords to break them. Other security information that is stored in the `/etc/shadow` file (such as expiration) could also be useful to subvert additional user accounts.
audit.remediation: Remove all users form the shadow group

audit.description: Disable the installation and use of file systems that are not required (hfs)
audit.impact: An attacker could use a vulnerability in hfs to elevate privileges
audit.remediation: Add a file to the /etc/modprob.d directory that disables hfs or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-unnecessary-kernel-mods'

audit.description: Disable the installation and use of file systems that are not required (hfsplus)
audit.impact: An attacker could use a vulnerability in hfsplus to elevate privileges
audit.remediation: Add a file to the /etc/modprob.d directory that disables hfsplus or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-unnecessary-kernel-mods'

audit.description: Disable the installation and use of file systems that are not required (jffs2)
audit.impact: An attacker could use a vulnerability in jffs2 to elevate privileges
audit.remediation: Add a file to the /etc/modprob.d directory that disables jffs2 or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-unnecessary-kernel-mods'

audit.description: Kernels should only be compiled from approved sources.
audit.impact: A kernel from an unapproved source could contain vulnerabilities or backdoors to grant access to an attacker.
audit.remediation: Install the kernel that is provided by your distro vendor.

audit.description: /etc/shadow file permissions should be set to 0400
audit.impact: An attacker that can retrieve or manipulate hashed passwords from /etc/shadow if it is not correctly secured.
audit.remediation: Set the permissions and ownership of /etc/shadow* or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-etc-shadow-perms'

audit.description: /etc/shadow- file permissions should be set to 0400
audit.impact: An attacker that can retrieve or manipulate hashed passwords from /etc/shadow- if it is not correctly secured.
audit.remediation: Set the permissions and ownership of /etc/shadow* or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-etc-shadow-perms'

audit.description: /etc/gshadow file permissions should be set to 0400
audit.impact: An attacker could join security groups if this file is not properly secured
audit.remediation: Set the permissions and ownership of /etc/gshadow- or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-etc-gshadow-perms'

audit.description: /etc/gshadow- file permissions should be set to 0400
audit.impact: An attacker could join security groups if this file is not properly secured
audit.remediation: Set the permissions and ownership of /etc/gshadow or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-etc-gshadow-perms'

audit.description: /etc/passwd file permissions should be 0644
audit.impact: An attacker could modify userIDs and login shells
audit.remediation: Set the permissions and ownership of /etc/passwd or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-etc-passwd-perms'

audit.description: /etc/group file permissions should be 0644
audit.impact: An attacker could elevate privileges by modifying group membership
audit.remediation: Set the permissions and ownership of /etc/group or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-etc-group-perms

audit.description: /etc/passwd- file permissions should be set to 0600
audit.impact: An attacker could join security groups if this file is not properly secured
audit.remediation: Set the permissions and ownership of /etc/passwd- or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-etc-passwd-perms

audit.description: /etc/group- file permissions should be 0644
audit.impact: An attacker could elevate privileges by modifying group membership
audit.remediation: Set the permissions and ownership of /etc/group- or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-etc-group-perms

audit.description: Access to the root account via su should be restricted to the 'root' group
audit.impact: An attacker could escalate permissions by password guessing if su is not restricted to users in the root group.
audit.remediation: Run the command '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r fix-su-permissions'. This will add the line 'auth required pam_wheel.so use_uid' to the file '/etc/pam.d/su'

audit.description: The 'root' group should exist, and contain all members who can su to root
audit.impact: An attacker could escalate permissions by password guessing if su is not restricted to users in the root group.
audit.remediation: Create the root group via the command 'groupadd -g 0 root'

audit.description: There are no accounts without passwords
audit.impact: An attacker can login to accounts with no password and execute arbitrary commands.
audit.remediation: Use the passwd command to set passwords for all accounts

audit.description: Accounts other than root must have unique UIDs greater than zero(0)
audit.impact: If an account other than root has uid zero, an attacker could compromise the account and gain root privileges.
audit.remediation: Assign unique, non-zero uids to all non-root accounts using 'usermod -u'

audit.description: Randomized placement of virtual memory regions should be enabled
audit.impact: An attacker could write executable code to known regions in memory resulting in elevation of privilege
audit.remediation: Add the value '1' or '2' to the file '/proc/sys/kernel/randomize_va_space'

audit.description: Kernel support for the XD/NX processor feature should be enabled
audit.impact: An attacker could cause a system to executable code from data regions in memory resulting in elevation of privilege.
audit.remediation: Confirm the file '/proc/cpuinfo' contains the flag 'nx'

audit.description: The '.' should not appear in root's $PATH
audit.impact: An attacker could elevate privileges by placing a malicious file in root's $PATH
audit.remediation: Modify the 'export PATH=' line in /root/.profile

audit.description: User home directories should be mode 750 or more restrictive
audit.impact: An attacker could retrieve sensitive information from the home folders of other users.
audit.remediation: Set home folder permissions to 750 or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r fix-home-dir-permissions

audit.description: The default umask for all users should be set to 077 in login.defs
audit.impact: An attacker could retrieve sensitive information from files owned by other users.
audit.remediation: Run the command '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-default-user-umask'. This will add the line 'UMASK 077' to the file '/etc/login.defs'

audit.description: All bootloaders should have password protection enabled.
audit.impact: An attacker with physical access could modify bootloader options, yielding unrestricted system access
audit.remediation: Add a boot loader password to the file '/boot/grub/grub.cfg'

audit.description: Ensure permissions on bootloader config are configured
audit.impact: Setting the permissions to read and write for root only prevents non-root users from seeing the boot parameters or changing them. Non-root users who read the boot parameters may be able to identify weaknesses in security upon boot and be able to exploit them.
audit.remediation: Set the owner and group of your bootloader to root:root and permissions to 0400 or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r bootloader-permissions

audit.description: Ensure authentication required for single user mode.
audit.impact: Requiring authentication in single user mode prevents an unauthorized user from rebooting the system into single user to gain root privileges without credentials.
audit.remediation: run the following command to set a password for the root user: `passwd root`

audit.description: Ensure packet redirect sending is disabled.
audit.impact: An attacker could use a compromised host to send invalid ICMP redirects to other router devices in an attempt to corrupt routing and have users access a system set up by the attacker as opposed to a valid system.
audit.remediation: set the following parameters in /etc/sysctl.conf: 'net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects = 0' and 'net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects = 0' or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-send-redirects

audit.description: Sending ICMP redirects should be disabled for all interfaces. (net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects = 0)
audit.impact: An attacker could alter this system's routing table, redirecting traffic to an alternate destination
audit.remediation: Run `sysctl -w key=value` and set to a compliant value or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-accept-redirects'.

audit.description: Sending ICMP redirects should be disabled for all interfaces. (net.ipv4.conf.default.secure_redirects = 0)
audit.impact: An attacker could alter this system's routing table, redirecting traffic to an alternate destination
audit.remediation: Run `sysctl -w key=value` and set to a compliant value or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-secure-redirects'

audit.description: Accepting source routed packets should be disabled for all interfaces. (net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route = 0)
audit.impact: An attacker could redirect traffic for malicious purposes.
audit.remediation: Run `sysctl -w key=value` and set to a compliant value or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-accept-source-route'

audit.description: Accepting source routed packets should be disabled for all interfaces. (net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route = 0) or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-accept-source-route'
audit.impact: An attacker could redirect traffic for malicious purposes.
audit.remediation: Run `sysctl -w key=value` and set to a compliant value.

audit.description: Ignoring bogus ICMP responses to broadcasts should be enabled. (net.ipv4.icmp_ignore_bogus_error_responses = 1)
audit.impact: An attacker could perform an ICMP attack resulting in DoS
audit.remediation: Run `sysctl -w key=value` and set to a compliant value or run or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r enable-icmp-ignore-bogus-error-responses'

audit.description: Ignoring ICMP echo requests (pings) sent to broadcast / multicast addresses should be enabled. (net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts = 1)
audit.impact: An attacker could perform an ICMP attack resulting in DoS
audit.remediation: Run `sysctl -w key=value` and set to a compliant value or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r enable-icmp-echo-ignore-broadcasts'

audit.description: Logging of martian packets (those with impossible addresses) should be enabled for all interfaces. (net.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians = 1)
audit.impact: An attacker could send traffic from spoofed addresses without being detected
audit.remediation: Run `sysctl -w key=value` and set to a compliant value or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r enable-log-martians'

audit.description: Performing source validation by reverse path should be enabled for all interfaces. (net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter = 1)
audit.impact: The system will accept traffic from addresses that are unroutable.
audit.remediation: Run `sysctl -w key=value` and set to a compliant value or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r enable-rp-filter'

audit.description: Performing source validation by reverse path should be enabled for all interfaces. (net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter = 1)
audit.impact: The system will accept traffic from addresses that are unroutable.
audit.remediation: Run `sysctl -w key=value` and set to a compliant value or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r enable-rp-filter'

audit.description: TCP syncookies should be enabled. (net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies = 1)
audit.impact: An attacker could perform a DoS over TCP
audit.remediation: Run `sysctl -w key=value` and set to a compliant value or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r enable-tcp-syncookies'

audit.description: The system should not act as a network sniffer.
audit.impact: An attacker may use promiscuous interfaces to sniff network traffic
audit.remediation: Promiscuous mode is enabled via a 'promisc' entry in '/etc/network/interfaces' or '/etc/rc.local.' Check both files and remove this entry.

audit.description: All wireless interfaces should be disabled.
audit.impact: An attacker could create a fake AP to intercept transmissions.
audit.remediation: Confirm all wireless interfaces are disabled in '/etc/network/interfaces'

audit.description: The IPv6 protocol should be enabled.
audit.impact: This is necessary for communication on modern networks.
audit.remediation: Open /etc/sysctl.conf and confirm that 'net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6' and 'net.ipv6.conf.default.disable_ipv6' are set to 0

audit.description: Ensure DCCP is disabled
audit.impact: If the protocol is not required, it is recommended that the drivers not be installed to reduce the potential attack surface.
audit.remediation: Edit or create a file in the `/etc/modprobe.d/` directory ending in .conf and add `install dccp /bin/true` then unload the dccp module or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-unnecessary-kernel-mods'

audit.description: Ensure SCTP is disabled
audit.impact: If the protocol is not required, it is recommended that the drivers not be installed to reduce the potential attack surface.
audit.remediation: Edit or create a file in the `/etc/modprobe.d/` directory ending in .conf and add `install sctp /bin/true` then unload the sctp module or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-unnecessary-kernel-mods'

audit.description: Disable support for RDS.
audit.impact: An attacker could use a vulnerability in RDS to compromise the system
audit.remediation: Edit or create a file in the `/etc/modprobe.d/` directory ending in .conf and add `install rds /bin/true` then unload the rds module or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-unnecessary-kernel-mods'

audit.description: Ensure TIPC is disabled
audit.impact: If the protocol is not required, it is recommended that the drivers not be installed to reduce the potential attack surface.
audit.remediation: Edit or create a file in the `/etc/modprobe.d/` directory ending in .conf and add `install tipc /bin/true` then unload the tipc module or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-unnecessary-kernel-mods'

audit.description: Ensure logging is configured
audit.impact: A great deal of important security-related information is sent via `rsyslog` (e.g., successful and failed su attempts, failed login attempts, root login attempts, etc.).
audit.remediation: Configure syslog, rsyslog or syslog-ng as appropriate

audit.description: The syslog, rsyslog, or syslog-ng package should be installed.
audit.impact: Reliability and security issues will not be logged, preventing proper diagnosis.
audit.remediation: Install the rsyslog package, or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r install-rsyslog'

audit.description: Ensure a loging service is enabled

audit.impact: On many systems, only the system administrator is authorized to schedule `cron` jobs. Using the `cron.allow` file to control who can run `cron` jobs enforces this policy. It is easier to manage an allow list than a deny list. In a deny list, you could potentially add a user ID to the system and forget to add it to the deny files.

audit.description: Ensure remote login warning banner is configured properly.
audit.impact: Warning messages inform users who are attempting to login to the system of their legal status regarding the system and must include the name of the organization that owns the system and any monitoring policies that are in place. Displaying OS and patch level information in login banners also has the side effect of providing detailed system information to attackers attempting to target specific exploits of a system. Authorized users can easily get this information by running the `uname -a`command once they have logged in.
audit.remediation: Remove any instances of \m \r \s and \v from the /etc/issue.net file

audit.description: Ensure password expiration is 365 days or less.
audit.impact: The window of opportunity for an attacker to leverage compromised credentials or successfully compromise credentials via an online brute force attack is limited by the age of the password. Therefore, reducing the maximum age of a password also reduces an attacker's window of opportunity.
audit.remediation: Set the `PASS_MAX_DAYS` parameter to no more than 365 in `/etc/login.defs` or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r configure-password-policy-max-days'

audit.description: Ensure password expiration warning days is 7 or more.
audit.impact: Providing an advance warning that a password will be expiring gives users time to think of a secure password. Users caught unaware may choose a simple password or write it down where it may be discovered.
audit.remediation: Set the `PASS_WARN_AGE` parameter to 7 in `/etc/login.defs` or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r configure-password-policy-warn-age'

audit.description: Ensure password reuse is limited.
audit.impact: Forcing users not to reuse their past 5 passwords make it less likely that an attacker will be able to guess the password.
audit.remediation: Ensure the 'remember' option is set to at least 5 in either /etc/pam.d/common-password or both /etc/pam.d/password_auth and /etc/pam.d/system_auth or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r configure-password-policy-history'

audit.description: Ensure password hashing algorithm is SHA-512
audit.impact: The SHA-512 algorithm provides much stronger hashing than MD5, thus providing additional protection to the system by increasing the level of effort for an attacker to successfully determine passwords. Note that these change only apply to accounts configured on the local system.
audit.remediation: Set password hashing algorithm to sha512. Many distributions provide tools for updating PAM configuration, consult your documentation for details. If no tooling is provided edit the appropriate `/etc/pam.d/` configuration file and add or modify the `pam_unix.so` lines to include the sha512 option: ``` password sufficient pam_unix.so sha512 ```

audit.description: Ensure minimum days between password changes is 7 or more.
audit.impact: By restricting the frequency of password changes, an administrator can prevent users from repeatedly changing their password in an attempt to circumvent password reuse controls.
audit.remediation: Set the `PASS_MIN_DAYS` parameter to 7 in `/etc/login.defs: `PASS_MIN_DAYS 7`. Modify user parameters for all users with a password set to match: `chage --mindays 7` or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-pass-min-days'

audit.description: Ensure all users last password change date is in the past
audit.impact: If a users recorded password change date is in the future then they could bypass any set password expiration.
audit.remediation: Ensure inactive password lock is 30 days or less Run the following command to set the default password inactivity period to 30 days: ``` # useradd -D -f 30 ``` Modify user parameters for all users with a password set to match: ``` # chage --inactive 30 ```

audit.description: Ensure system accounts are non-login
audit.impact: It is important to make sure that accounts that are not being used by regular users are prevented from being used to provide an interactive shell. By default, Ubuntu sets the password field for these accounts to an invalid string, but it is also recommended that the shell field in the password file be set to `/usr/sbin/nologin`. This prevents the account from potentially being used to run any commands.
audit.remediation: Set the shell for any accounts returned by the audit script to `/sbin/nologin`

audit.description: Ensure default group for the root account is GID 0
audit.impact: Using GID 0 for the `_root_ `account helps prevent `_root_`-owned files from accidentally becoming accessible to non-privileged users.
audit.remediation: Run the following command to set the `root` user default group to GID `0` : ``` # usermod -g 0 root ```

audit.description: Ensure root is the only UID 0 account
audit.impact: This access must be limited to only the default `root `account and only from the system console. Administrative access must be through an unprivileged account using an approved mechanism.
audit.remediation: Remove any users other than `root` with UID `0` or assign them a new UID if appropriate.

audit.impact: For compliance

audit.description: Ensure auditd service is enabled
audit.impact: The capturing of system events provides system administrators with information to allow them to determine if unauthorized access to their system is occurring.
audit.remediation: Install audit package (systemctl enable auditd)

audit.description: Run AuditD service
audit.impact: The capturing of system events provides system administrators with information to allow them to determine if unauthorized access to their system is occurring.
audit.remediation: Run AuditD service (systemctl start auditd)

audit.description: Ensure SNMP Server is not enabled
audit.impact: The SNMP server can communicate using SNMP v1, which transmits data in the clear and does not require authentication to execute commands. Unless absolutely necessary, it is recommended that the SNMP service not be used. If SNMP is required the server should be configured to disallow SNMP v1.
audit.remediation: Run one of the following commands to disable `snmpd`: ``` # chkconfig snmpd off ``` ``` # systemctl disable snmpd ``` ``` # update-rc.d snmpd disable ```

audit.description: Ensure rsync service is not enabled
audit.impact: The `rsyncd` service presents a security risk as it uses unencrypted protocols for communication.
audit.remediation: Run one of the following commands to disable `rsyncd` : `chkconfig rsyncd off`, 'systemctl disable rsyncd`, `update-rc.d rsyncd disable` or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r disable-rsysnc'

audit.description: Ensure NIS server is not enabled
audit.impact: The NIS service is inherently an insecure system that has been vulnerable to DOS attacks, buffer overflows and has poor authentication for querying NIS maps. NIS generally been replaced by such protocols as Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP). It is recommended that the service be disabled and other, more secure services be used
audit.remediation: Run one of the following commands to disable `ypserv` : ``` # chkconfig ypserv off ``` ``` # systemctl disable ypserv ``` ``` # update-rc.d ypserv disable ```

audit.description: Ensure rsh client is not installed
audit.impact: These legacy clients contain numerous security exposures and have been replaced with the more secure SSH package. Even if the server is removed, it is best to ensure the clients are also removed to prevent users from inadvertently attempting to use these commands and therefore exposing their credentials. Note that removing the `rsh `package removes the clients for `rsh`, `rcp `and `rlogin`.
audit.remediation: Uninstall `rsh` using the appropriate package manager or manual installation: ``` yum remove rsh ``` ``` apt-get remove rsh ``` ``` zypper remove rsh ```

audit.description: Disable SMB V1 with Samba
audit.impact: SMB v1 has well-known, serious vulnerabilities and does not encrypt data in transit. If it must be used for overriding business reasons, it is strongly recommended that other mitigations be identified to compensate for the use of this protocol.
audit.remediation: If Samba is not running, remove package, otherwise there should be a line in the [global] section of /etc/samba/smb.conf: min protocol = SMB2 or run '/opt/microsoft/omsagent/plugin/omsremediate -r set-smb-min-version

action.script: for d in $(bash -l -c 'echo $PATH' | sed 's/:/ /g') do chmod og-w $d done

# (Audit 23.1) Disable login for system accounts for i in $(egrep -v '^([^:]*:){5}.*(root|home)' /etc/passwd | egrep -v '^([^:]*:){6}(/dev/null|/bin/false|/sbin/nologin|/usr/sbin/nologin)' | cut -d ":" -f 1; egrep '^syslog:' /etc/passwd | egrep -v '^syslog:([^:]*:){5}:(/dev/null|/bin/false|/sbin/nologin|/usr/sbin/nologin)' | cut -d ":" -f 1) do chsh -s /bin/false $i 2>/dev/null done

# (Audit6.1 - 6.6, 54, 55, 57) Disable unnecessary Kernel Modules cat > /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist-azurebaseline.conf <<EOF # Modules disabled per Azure baseline install dccp /bin/true install sctp /bin/true install rds /bin/true install tipc /bin/true install cramfs /bin/true install freevxfs /bin/true install hfs /bin/true install hfsplus /bin/true install jffs2 /bin/true install usb-storage /bin/true EOF chown root.root /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist-azurebaseline.conf chmod 644 /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist-azurebaseline.conf
sed -i 's/^#*\s*\(PASS_MAX_DAYS\s\+\)[0-9]\+/\170/g' /etc/login.defs
sed -i 's/^#*\s*\(PASS_WARN_AGE\s\+\)[0-9]\+/\115/g' /etc/login.defs

if [ -z "$(egrep '^\s*password\s+.+pam_unix.so.+remember=[0-9]' /etc/pam.d/common-password)" ]; then sed -i 's/^#*\s*\(password\s\+.\+pam_unix.so\s\+\)/\1remember=7 /g' /etc/pam.d/common-password else sed -i 's/^#*\s*\(password\s\+.\+pam_unix.so.\+\)remember=[0-9]/\1remember=7/g' /etc/pam.d/common-password fi
sysctl -w fs.suid_dumpable=0

remediation.description: Ensure permissions on /etc/motd /etc/issue /etc/hosts.allow /etc/hosts.deny and /etc/issue.net are configured
Set the permissions of logger config files
Set the minimum days between password changes to 7

action.script: if id games &>/dev/null; then userdel -r -f games fi

# Require SMB v2 if [ -n "$(egrep '^\s*min\sprotocol\s+=\s+SMB1' /etc/samba/smb.conf)" ]; then sed -i 's/\(^ *min *protocol *= *\)SMB1/\1SMB2/i' /etc/samba/smb.conf elif [ -z "$(egrep '^\s*min\sprotocol\s+=\s+SMB2' /etc/samba/smb.conf)" ]; then sed -i 's/\(^\[global\].*$\)/\1\nmin protocol = SMB2/i' /etc/samba/smb.conf fi
